rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The synthesis, storage and release of acetylcholine in the superior cervical ganglion of the cat
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The acetylcholine (ACh) stores of cat sympathetic ganglia were determined following a variety of patterns of preganglionic nerve stimulation and poet-stimulation rest periods. They increased by 38% over a 20 min rest following 60 min, 20/sec stimulation and remained elevated for at least 3 hr. The increase was less with 10 min stimulation and absent with 4/sec stimulation. The excess ACh was released during stimulation in the presence of hemicholinium-3. The time course or Ach release from stimulated plasma-perfused ganglia was followed. The release rate was highest near the onset of 20/sec stimulation and declined over 5 min to a 50% lower steady value. At 4/sec the rate increased over the first 5 min to a 25% higher steady value. These findings are discussed in relation to the hypothesis of preferential release of newly synthesized transmitter and the two compartment model of transmitter storage.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology
